title: Traffic stop

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: Traffic stop
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am seeking the following information regarding a traffic stop conducted on September 6th late night and/or September 7th early morning hours, within the city limits of Laredo,Texas. 
subject involved
Harrison Byars
DOB 11/30/1985
Citations issued-
Driving without CDL
driving without headlights
The records being sought are the following
Any and all dispatch logs, police blotters, logs, reports, documents, gathered, filed, and/or transferred in relation to this traffic stop. With all relevant and applicable public information surrounding the reasons for the stop, the time duration of the stop, any and all reports made in relation to the results of the traffic stop.

I am also requesting any and all audio recordings, dash cam recording and/or video footage from the traffic stop by each officer involved in the traffic stop. 

I am also requesting any and all body worn audio and or video information obtained by the officer or officers involved in this traffic stop from the initial dispatch contact and or initial contact made with Harrison Byars through and for the entirety of the traffic stop.


eff. January 1, 2025.
Art. 2B.0112.
RELEASE OF INFORMATION RECORDED BY BODY WORN
CAMERA.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Allison

communications.subject: Open Records Request :: W040284-033125
communications.communication:
Welcome to the City of Laredo Open Records Center. We have received your Public Information Request, and it has been diverted to the appropriate department for processing. Pursuant to the Public Information Act, the governmental body will try to complete the request within a reasonable amount of time depending on the nature of the request. However, you can expect to receive notification should the request require more than 10 business days to complete. 

Please note, the Texas Public Information Act does not require a governmental body to create new information, to do legal research, or to answer questions. The request must ask for records or information already in existence. In addition, the City of Laredo may collect a fee as prescribed by law or regulation for the requested documents. If a fee is not prescribed by law or regulation, the fee shall be the actual cost of duplicating the record(s) and any applicable labor costs. 

Finally, you can monitor the progress of your request through the automated open records center on the City of Laredo website .  Unfortunately, this email is an automated notification, which is unable to receive replies. Therefore, if you have any questions with respect to a pending request or pertaining to any open records issue,  you may directly contact this office through the open records center.  You may also reach us by phone at the number below. 

Very truly yours, 

City Attorney's Office 
Public Information Coordinator for the City of Laredo 
1110 Houston Street 
City Hall, 3rd Floor 
Laredo, Texas 78040 
(956) 791-7319 Telephone 
(956) 791-7494 Facsimile

title: DOGE IT Policies (Certified Mail)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: DOGE IT Policies (Certified Mail)
communications.communication:
Department of Government Efficiency
Eisenhower Executive Office Building
1650 17th St NW
Washington, DC 20006

Re: Freedom of Information Act Request

Dear FOIA Officer:
We submit this request under the Freedom of Information Act (“FOIA”), 5 U.S.C. § 552, to the Department of Government Efficiency (“DOGE”) on behalf of the MuckRock Foundation (“MuckRock”).

Requested Records
MuckRock requests all records from January 20, 2025 to the present concerning information security policies and procedures adopted by the DOGE. Specifically, MuckRock requests the following records:

1) Copies of any Information Security Policies, Cybersecurity Policies, or IT Security Policies generated by or enacted by the DOGE, including but not limited to:
* Network security
* Employee cybersecurity training requirements
* Use of personal devices for government work
* Data retention and deletion policies for electronic communications
2) Copies of any lists of prohibited or allowed software, services and other devices in use by the DOGE Staff.
3) Copies of any Security Incident Response Plan and any documented standard operating procedures for responding to cybersecurity incidents adopted by the DOGE.
4) Copies of any security incident response reports and cybersecurity incident logs maintained by the DOGE.

Request for News Media Requester Status
MuckRock requests a limitation on search and review fees on the grounds that they are a “representative of the news media” and do not seek the requested records for commercial use.¹ Accordingly, fees associated with the processing of this request should be limited to reasonable duplication costs.

MuckRock “actively gathers information of potential interest to a segment of the public, uses its editorial skills to turn the raw materials into a distinct work, and distributes that work to an audience.”² Specifically, MuckRock is an internationally recognized non-profit news outlet, that regularly covers issues of public importance through the original analysis of primary source materials, particularly government records. This analysis is made available to the public via MuckRock’s website. MuckRock intends to use its editorial skills to turn any information obtained through this request into a report, article, or other relevant product, freely distributed to educate the public.

Request for Expedited Processing
MuckRock requests expedited processing pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E). There is a “compelling need” for these records because the information requested is “urgen[tly]” needed by an organization primarily engaged in disseminating information “to inform the public concerning actual or alleged Federal Government activity.”³

First, the requested records seek to inform the public about the USDS’s information security policies. There is a compelling and urgent need to inform the public about the policies the USDS has adopted to protect itself against cybersecurity incidents and safeguard its data. As of the filing of this request, lawmakers, reporters, and the general public have expressed interest and concern as to the steps the USDS has taken to ensure operational and cybersecurity.⁴

Second, MuckRock is “primarily engaged in disseminating information” within the meaning of the FOIA. 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(v)(II). See also 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(1)(ii). MuckRock is a Massachusetts-based 501(c)(3) non-profit organization that brings together journalists, researchers, activists, and regular citizens to request, analyze, and share government documents. It provides a repository of hundreds of thousands of pages of original government materials,⁵ as well as original reporting and analysis,⁶ particularly in the areas of government spending, surveillance, and public safety. MuckRock’s publications are broadly circulated to the public and widely available at no cost.

MuckRock intends to analyze, publish, and disseminate to the public information gathered through this request. The records requested are not sought for commercial use and MuckRock plans to disseminate the information disclosed as a result of this request to the public at no cost.

Given the foregoing, the request satisfies the requirements for expedited processing. Pursuant to applicable statutes and regulations, MuckRock expect a determination regarding expedited processing within 10 days. See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(ii); 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(4).

Request for Records in Electronic Format
MuckRock requests that responsive electronic records be provided electronically in their native file format, if possible.⁷

Alternatively, MuckRock requests that the records be provided electronically in text-searchable PDF, in the best image quality in the USDS’s possession, and in separate, Bates-stamped files. MuckRock further requests that you provide an estimated date on which you will finish processing this request.⁸

***
If this FOIA request is denied in whole or in part, please provide the reasons for the denial, pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A)(i). In addition, please release all segregable portions of otherwise exempt material in accordance with 5 U.S.C. § 552(b).

Thank you for your consideration of this request. If you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to contact me at the email address below.

Yours, 
/s/ Michael Morisy,
Michael Morisy, Chief Executive Officer
MuckRock Foundation

By their counsel 
/s/ Mason A. Kortz 
Mason Kortz, Clinical Instructor 
Harvard Law School Cyberlaw Clinic

__________________________
¹ 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(ii)(II).
² 6 C.F.R. § 5.11(b)(6).
³ 5 U.S.C § 552(a)(6)(E)(v)(II)
⁴ See, e.g., David Klepper, DOGE Access to US Intelligence Secrets Poses a National Security Threat, Democrats Say, Associated Press (Feb. 27, 2025), https://apnews.com/article/doge-musk-trump-democrats-intelligence-russia-threat-ffee435b1e65a0ac1d34889c89c30d10.
⁵ See MuckRock, Requests (lasted accessed Feb. 27, 2025), https://www.muckrock.com/foi/list/.
⁶ See MuckRock, News (last accessed Feb. 27, 2025), https://www.muckrock.com/news/.
⁷ 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(3)(B).
⁸ Id. § 552(a)(7)(B)(ii).

1650 17th St NW

Re: Freedom of Information Act Request

Requested Records

1. Any “Assignment Agreements” that have been generated between the USDS and any other agencies or departments that mention FOIA and/or media questions.
2. A copy of any notifications sent from an agency to the USDS under the process outlined above.
3. A copy of any communications regarding the policy of notifications about FOIA requests sent from another agency to the USDS.
4. Any logs maintained by the USDS that detail or track such requests, including any fields that might be captured in such a log.

Given the foregoing, the request satisfies the requirements for expedited processing. Pursuant to applicable statutes and regulations, MuckRock expect a determination regarding expedited processing within 10 days. See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(ii); 6 C.F.R. § 5.5(e)(4).

MuckRock requests that responsive electronic records be provided electronically in their native file format, if possible.⁷

Alternatively, MuckRock requests that the records be provided electronically in text-searchable PDF, in the best image quality in the USDS’s possession, and in separate, Bates-stamped files. MuckRock further requests that you provide an estimated date on which you will finish processing this request.⁸

Thank you for your consideration of this request. If you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to contact me at the email address below.

Yours, 
/s/ Michael Morisy
Michael Morisy, Chief Executive Officer
MuckRock Foundation

By their counsel 
/s/ Mason A. Kortz 
Mason Kortz, Clinical Instructor 
Harvard Law School Cyberlaw Clinic

__________________________
¹ 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(ii)(II).
² 6 C.F.R. § 5.11(b)(6).
³ 5 U.S.C § 552(a)(6)(E)(v)(II)
⁴ See, e.g., David Klepper, DOGE Access to US Intelligence Secrets Poses a National Security Threat, Democrats Say, Associated Press (Feb. 27, 2025), https://apnews.com/article/doge-musk-trump-democrats-intelligence-russia-threat-ffee435b1e65a0ac1d34889c89c30d10.
⁵ See MuckRock, Requests (lasted accessed Feb. 27, 2025), https://www.muckrock.com/foi/list/.
⁶ See MuckRock, News (last accessed Feb. 27, 2025), https://www.muckrock.com/news/.
⁷ 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(3)(B).
⁸ Id. § 552(a)(7)(B)(ii).

title: DOD Encrypted Messaging

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: DOD Encrypted Messaging
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all documents, emails, text messages and calendar entries from the leadership of the Office of the Secretary of Defense that mention the term "Signal," referring to the encrypted messaging application. The leadership I am referring to includes Pete Hegseth, Steve Feinberg and Christopher Grady. I am requesting records from January 21, 2025 until the present day.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matt Bernardini

title: Executive Order 14188 ("Additional Measures to Combat Anti-Semitism") 60-Day Report (Education)

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of the report required by Executive Order 14188 at §3(a). Executive Order 14188 is available at https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/01/additional-measures-to-combat-anti-semitism. Executive Order 14188 requires a report by each agency concerning "authorities or actions" that "might be used to curb or combat anti-Semitism."
I request that this request be expedited under 34 CFR § 5.21(i)(2)(i)(B) for the following reasons:

1. I certify the following to be true and correct: My organization is primarily engaged in disseminating information. The Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression (FIRE) maintains a news website at https://thefire.org/news, through which its staff members regularly publish news stories and editorial content concerning the activities of governments, government officials, and other persons or organizations of public concern. I am a staff member of FIRE. I frequently write about matters involving the First Amendment and academic freedom, including on FIRE's website. See, e.g., https://www.thefire.org/news-archive?author=303. A substantial component of my duties as a staff member of FIRE is to obtain information through public records requests, including through the Freedom of Information Act, which I or my colleagues then share through FIRE's website and social media channels. I also publish news and other information of public concern via "X" (https://x.com/adamsteinbaugh) and "Bluesky" (https://bsky.app/profile/adamsteinbaugh.bsky.social).

2. The requested information concerns an actual or alleged government activity, namely the Department's response to an Executive Order concerning activity or expression that may be protected by the First Amendment.

3. The requested information extends beyond the public's right to know about government activity generally and instead has a particular value that would be lost if not processed on an expedited basis. The information pertains to a news story of public interest. That issue has attracted a wide range of news media coverage, including the numerous articles identified below, which are helpful in establishing that there is an urgency to inform the public on this topic.

In addition to the significant range of news coverage relating to the Trump administration's response to anti-semitism, particularly as it relates to higher education, examples of recent articles demonstrating the public's ongoing and current interest in this information include these articles:

https://www.algemeiner.com/2025/01/30/this-failure-ends-today-trump-issues-major-executive-order-campus-antisemitism/
https://www.wsj.com/opinion/mr-trump-investigate-my-campus-hamas-rape-denial-hostile-environment-for-jews-and-women-politics-77dec881
https://www.commentary.org/seth-mandel/trumps-new-executive-order-on-anti-semitism/
https://reason.com/volokh/2025/02/03/may-aliens-be-deported-based-on-their-speech/
https://www.newsmax.com/newsmax-tv/alan-dershowitz-donald-trump-antisemitism/2025/01/29/id/1197083/
https://www.newsmax.com/newsmax-tv/mike-huckabee-donald-trump-antisemitism/2025/01/29/id/1197085/
https://legalinsurrection.com/2025/01/trump-signs-executive-orders-dealing-with-antisemitism-critical-race-theory-in-education/
https://www.campusreform.org/article/roundup-trump-issues-executive-orders-deport-hamas-lovers-protect-school-choice-fight-back-dei-/27390
https://www.dailyuw.com/news/trump-executive-order-directs-universities-to-monitor-for-and-report-activities-of-foreign-students/article_958cc45e-e0cf-11ef-8072-0731e3bb9e5e.html
https://www.purdueexponent.org/opinion/editorials/palestine-editorial-exponent-protest/article_fa7a8626-e025-11ef-bf4b-d7af2a263c11.html
https://www.columbiaspectator.com/news/2025/01/30/trump-issues-executive-order-to-combat-campus-anti-semitism-report-activities-by-alien-students
https://dailynorthwestern.com/2025/02/10/opinion/bernstein-as-a-jewish-student-the-executive-order-on-antisemitism-doesnt-speak-for-me

REQUEST FOR A FEE WAIVER OR REDUCED FEES:

I request, under 34 CFR § 5.21(b), a waiver or reduction of fees for the following reasons:

1. Disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest because its disclosure would shed light on the operations or activities of the government. The requested information pertains specifically to the Department's response to protests on college campuses. The Department has made a concerted effort to draw public attention to its activities in this regard.

2. Disclosure of the requested information would be likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of those operations or activities. Disclosure of the requested information would meaningfully inform the public about the Department's activities and operations.

3. Disclosure of the requested information will contribute to the understanding of a reasonably broad audience of persons interested in the subject, as opposed to the individual understanding of the requester. The requestor is a licensed attorney who practices First Amendment law. As such, the requestor will be able to effectively convey information to the public. Further, the requestor is a representative of the news media. The requestor and his employer, the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression, gather information of potential interest to a segment of the public, turns that information into distinct works (including through its news website, located at https://thefire.org/news), and distributes that information to the public. The information requested here relates to information that is about current events or that would be of current interest to the public. The requestor's past publication record (in addition to FIRE's articles available at https://thefire.org/news) is available at https://www.thefire.org/news-archive?author=303.

4. The requested information is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester. The requestor works for a nonprofit organization and the records are not sought for a commercial purpose.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

title: Public Information Act Request – Department Manual and Officer Gregory Ceraso Disciplinary History

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: Public Information Act Request – Department Manual and Officer Gregory Ceraso Disciplinary History
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Dear Records Custodian,

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, Chapter 552 of the Texas Government Code, I respectfully request access to a copy of the Dallas Police Department’s full and current policy and procedures manual. This includes, but is not limited to:

General Orders

Department Handbook

Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs)

Rules and Regulations Manual

Any written directives, protocols, or administrative manuals governing:

Officer conduct

Traffic enforcement procedures

Use of force

Body-worn camera policy

Complaint intake and internal investigations

Search and seizure

Arrest protocols

Vehicle stops and detentions

Personnel accountability

Any other department-wide operational guidance

In addition, I request access to all internal and external complaints, disciplinary actions, and investigative findings involving Officer Gregory Ceraso from the start of his employment with the Dallas Police Department to the end of his tenure there. This includes:

Citizen complaints (sustained, not sustained, unfounded, or exonerated)

Internal affairs investigations

Records of suspension, demotion, written reprimands, or terminations

Use-of-force reviews or reports

Any civil rights or misconduct claims involving Officer Ceraso

If any portion of the requested records is considered exempt, I request that you provide all non-exempt portions and include a written explanation referencing the applicable exemption(s) under Texas Government Code § 552.301.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Wayne

title: Public Information Act Request – Department Manual and Officer Gregory Ceraso Disciplinary History

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: Public Information Act Request – Department Manual and Officer Gregory Ceraso Disciplinary History
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Dear Records Custodian,

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, Chapter 552 of the Texas Government Code, I respectfully request access to a copy of the Gun Barrel City Police Department’s full and current policy and procedures manual. This includes, but is not limited to:

General Orders

Department Handbook

Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs)

Rules and Regulations Manual

Any written directives, protocols, or administrative manuals governing:

Officer conduct

Traffic enforcement procedures

Use of force

Body-worn camera policy

Complaint intake and internal investigations

Search and seizure

Arrest protocols

Vehicle stops and detentions

Personnel accountability

Any other department-wide operational guidance

In addition, I request access to all internal and external complaints, disciplinary actions, and investigative findings involving Officer Gregory Ceraso from the start of his employment with the Gun Barrel City Police Department to the present. This includes:

Citizen complaints (sustained, not sustained, unfounded, or exonerated)

Internal affairs investigations

Records of suspension, demotion, written reprimands, or terminations

Use-of-force reviews or reports

Any civil rights or misconduct claims involving Officer Ceraso

If any portion of the requested records is considered exempt, I request that you provide all non-exempt portions and include a written explanation referencing the applicable exemption(s) under Texas Government Code § 552.301.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Wayne

communications.subject: Your Skagit County, WA public records request #25-279 has been submitted.
communications.communication:
Skagit County, WA ************************************************************************ Your record request #25-279 has been submitted successfully. Thank you for submitting your request to Skagit County Records Department. Someone from our records team will respond as required by RCW 42.56.520, within five business days. ln calculating the five business days, the following are not counted: the day the county receives the request, Saturdays, Sundays and holidays. RCW 1.12.040. See also WAC 44-14-03006. lf the request is received by the County after County business hours. the request shall be deemed to have been received by the county on the next business day. A response may be (a) providing the records, (b) providing a link to records available online, (c) providing a reasonable estimated date of when the records will be available, (d) requesting clarification, or (e) denial of the request. If you have any questions or concerns, please contact me at 360-416-1152, or by email at pherman@co.skagit.wa.us. Sincerely, Pamela Herman Certified Public Records Officer, Central Services Skagit County 360-416-1152 Public Records Act (PRA) Notice. Any information, including certain personal information, submitted to the County by e-mail or other method may be subject to disclosure as a public record under RCW chapter 42.56.  As the requester, you can always see the status of your request by signing into the Skagit County, WA portal. If you haven't already signed in, you may need to activate or setup your account to get started. Once your account is activated, you can communicate directly with the Skagit County, WA through NextRequest. ************************************************************************ Reply to this email or sign in to contact Skagit County, WA.

This letter serves as Walla Walla County’s initial five-day letter, pursuant to RCW 42.56.520, to your public records request. After your request is reviewed for content and we determine the department or office in which your request refers to, the County will provide an estimate to provide an initial installment of responsive records. After locating responsive records, the County will determine whether any of the responsive documents are subject to applicable exemptions under the Public Records Act, and to notify any third parties affected by the request. If third party notification is required, twenty (20) business days will be allowed for a response by the third party to those records which specifically pertain to them. communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request: Brady List (March 2025) (Wahkiakum County Prosecuting Attorney)
communications.communication:
Hi, there’s been no change in status since last year: no responsive records. Not necessarily because we’re so virtuous, but because Brady-worthy officers are rare and Wahkiakum County is very small.

We do have a state highway that state troopers patrols, but when I see a new trooper’s name on a ticket, I consult the WSP Brady list, which I assume you have already requested directly from them. Since I neither have nor maintain that list, I’m assuming that you are not requesting it from me. Last couple of times we (i.e. muckrock.com and me) did this, you were OK with that, and I hope you still are!

New Washington State case law requires me to say the following things:


  *   I believe you have received all the information called for in your request, which is none because I don’t have any responsive records.
  *   I believe this request is closed.
  *   Because the request is closed, the statute of limitations on any public records lawsuit begins to run today.
  *   If you do not believe this request is fully satisfied, if you think there’s been a misunderstanding between us about what you were asking for, if there’s any reason you can think of why this request should stay open, please notify me within a reasonable time – say, two weeks?

Thanks for putting up with the disclaimers. Have a great day!

title: Public Records Request – Portland Parks Considered for Closure

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Maine Freedom of Access Act, I hereby request the following records:

To: Portland Parks, Recreation & Facilities Department
From: David Lide, Publisher, Maine Times
📧 david.lide@mainetimes.com
📰 news@mainetimes.com
📞 1-800-488-1820

Dear Records Officer,

Under the Maine Freedom of Access Act (1 M.R.S. § 401 et seq.), I respectfully submit this request on behalf of Maine Times, a privately held statewide news outlet focused on in-depth public-interest reporting and community accountability.

As part of an editorial series exploring access to public space and municipal infrastructure, Maine Times is requesting information about any Portland city parks or recreational facilities currently under internal review for closure, sale, or long-term service reductions.

Records Requested:
Please provide any lists, internal reports, memos, or summaries generated between January 1, 2022 and present that identify:

Parks or recreational facilities being considered for:

Closure, sale, repurposing, or permanent restricted access

Operational changes due to budget shortfalls, maintenance issues, or underutilization

If a formal list does not exist, we welcome any documentation reflecting internal discussions or evaluations.

About Maine Times
Maine Times is a privately owned statewide news organization, built with the long-term goal of becoming Maine’s leading source for credible journalism. While our flagship website is currently in development, Maine Times is actively producing original reporting through the Maine Times podcast and additional editorial channels.

We are building with purpose: to inform the public, amplify community voices, and hold institutions to account—across the entire state of Maine.

We respectfully request digital delivery of the requested records. If this request would result in any fees, please notify us in advance.

Thank you for your time and service.

Sincerely,
David Lide
Publisher – Maine Times
📧 david.lide@mainetimes.com
📰 news@mainetimes.com
📞 1-800-488-1820
🌐 Mainetimes.com

Have a story tip, know someone who should be featured, or interested in advertising? Reach out.
Maine Times is a privately held company based in Dover, Delaware, and proudly serves readers across the state.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by 1 M.R.S.A. § 408(6). The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

David Lide

title: DOGE Access to Treasury Systems and IRS Communications (Internal Revenue Service)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: DOGE Access to Treasury Systems and IRS Communications (Internal Revenue Service)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All internal communications, emails, memorandums, or policy documents from January 1, 2024 to present that reference:
1. The Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE)
Elon Musk, in his role as leader of DOGE
2. The extent or nature of DOGE’s access to Treasury systems, including but not limited to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), the Bureau of the Fiscal Service, or any Treasury-managed financial systems
5. Any written agreements, memorandums of understanding (MOUs), access authorization forms, or audit trails/logs showing the scope, level, or duration of access granted to DOGE personnel or contractors.
4. Any risk assessments, internal reviews, or security evaluations performed in relation to DOGE’s access to Treasury data or systems.

I am not requesting individual taxpayer data or any protected personal information.

To assist with processing and reduce the burden, I am willing to accept:

1. Digital records only. 
2. Limited date range (January 1, 2024–present).
3. Redacted documents were legally necessary. 

I request a waiver of all fees in the public interest, as the release of this information is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of government operations.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kim Crooks

title: University of North Texas drag ban (University Of North Texas System)

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: University of North Texas drag ban (University Of North Texas System)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Any communications received, sent, or created by or for Chancellor Michael Williams, President Harrison Keller, Regent Laura Wright, Steve Moore, or any person employed by the University of North Texas System Office of Government Relations, on or after January 20, 2025, which either:

(a) concerns drag performances, including the GLAD Queer Alliance UNT Drag Show 2025 scheduled for April 10 and the UNT Gammas Drag Night with the Gammas scheduled for April 11; or 

(b) contains any of the following terms: "Executive Order", "gender ideology", "Queer Empowerment", "drag show", "drag shows", "drag performance", "drag performances", "drag night", "queer alliance", "YDSA", or "Young Democrats"; 

2. Any Title IX (or similar) complaint or report referencing the word "in drag", "drag performance", "drag show", "drag shows", or "drag performances". This request is limited to complaints filed on or after January 1, 2020.

3. Any records held by administrators or staff of the University of North Texas concerning the planning, logistics, or approval of (a) the GLAD Queer Alliance UNT Drag Show 2025 scheduled for April 10; or (b) the UNT Gammas Drag Night with the Gammas scheduled for April 11.

4. If the University of North Texas maintains a reservation system or database for event reservations, all entries (and records contained in the system) concerning (a) the GLAD Queer Alliance UNT Drag Show 2025 scheduled for April 10; or (b) the UNT Gammas Drag Night with the Gammas scheduled for April 11.

title: University of North Texas drag ban (University Of North Texas)

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: University of North Texas drag ban (University Of North Texas)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Any communications received, sent, or created by or for Chancellor Michael Williams, President Harrison Keller, Regent Laura Wright, Steve Moore, or any person employed by the University of North Texas System Office of Government Relations, on or after January 20, 2025, which either:

(a) concerns drag performances, including the GLAD Queer Alliance UNT Drag Show 2025 scheduled for April 10 and the UNT Gammas Drag Night with the Gammas scheduled for April 11; or 

(b) contains any of the following terms: "Executive Order", "gender ideology", "Queer Empowerment", "drag show", "drag shows", "drag performance", "drag performances", "drag night", "queer alliance", "YDSA", or "Young Democrats"; 

2. Any Title IX (or similar) complaint or report referencing the word "in drag", "drag performance", "drag show", "drag shows", or "drag performances". This request is limited to complaints filed on or after January 1, 2020.

3. Any records held by administrators or staff of the University of North Texas concerning the planning, logistics, or approval of (a) the GLAD Queer Alliance UNT Drag Show 2025 scheduled for April 10; or (b) the UNT Gammas Drag Night with the Gammas scheduled for April 11.

4. If the University of North Texas maintains a reservation system or database for event reservations, all entries (and records contained in the system) concerning (a) the GLAD Queer Alliance UNT Drag Show 2025 scheduled for April 10; or (b) the UNT Gammas Drag Night with the Gammas scheduled for April 11.

"Communications" means and includes emails, text messages, social media messages, letters, memoranda, calendar entries, chats, or any other form of one-to-one or one-to-many communication.

Please note that this request seeks public records wherever they may be found, including on devices or networks owned or operated by private parties. communications.communication:

Police Cam News

title: DOGE–CFPB Communications Regarding Agency Restructuring and Enforcement (Jan–Present)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: DOGE–CFPB Communications Regarding Agency Restructuring and Enforcement (Jan–Present)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Under the Freedom of Information Act, I request access to all communications (including emails, memos, or written directives) from January 1, 2025 to present between any representative of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) and CFPB leadership (including the Acting Director and Chief Operating Officer). Please note that a federal judge has ruled DOGE is subject to FOIA (CREW v. DOGE, March 10, 2025), and has ordered expedited processing and full document preservation. This request falls squarely within the scope of that ruling.

Please include any documents that discuss:

Agency restructuring

Staff reductions, layoffs, or reassignments

Budget changes

Suspension or freezing of enforcement activities

I am a private citizen requesting this information for personal, non-commercial use.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andy Dufresne
